breaking_news.title: China‑linked DKnife framework hijacks router traffic for espionage
breaking_news.summary:
Researchers uncovered the DKnife Linux toolkit, a seven‑component adversary‑in‑the‑middle framework used since 2019 to perform deep‑packet inspection, traffic manipulation, and malware delivery on edge routers. The toolkit is deployed by China‑aligned threat actors to compromise routers at the network edge, allowing them to spy on and inject malicious payloads into victim traffic.

The abuse impacts telecommunications providers, ISPs, government agencies, defense contractors, financial services and manufacturing firms that rely on compromised routing infrastructure. Because the compromise occurs at the network perimeter, detection is difficult, raising the risk of large‑scale data exfiltration and further downstream attacks.
threat_actors: China‑aligned threat actors (APT group associated with DKnife)

breaking_news.title: CISA alerts on unauthenticated SmarterMail RCE exploited by ransomware gangs
breaking_news.summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) issued an emergency warning about CVE‑2026‑24423, an unauthenticated remote‑code‑execution flaw in SmarterTools SmarterMail that allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands via crafted HTTP requests. Active exploitation has been observed in the wild, with ransomware operators leveraging the vulnerability to deploy encryptors on compromised mail servers.

Enterprises and service providers that run SmarterMail for email hosting are at immediate risk, as successful exploitation can lead to full server takeover and lateral movement within corporate networks. The rapid adoption of the flaw by ransomware groups elevates the threat to a critical level for any organization relying on SmarterMail for communications.
affected_entities: Enterprises using SmarterMail for corporate email

breaking_news.title: Supply‑chain attack compromises dYdX npm and PyPI packages
breaking_news.summary:
Security researchers discovered that legitimate npm and PyPI packages used by the dYdX cryptocurrency protocol were replaced with malicious versions that install wallet‑stealing modules and remote‑access trojans. The compromised packages, including @dydxprotocol/v4-client-js, were distributed through the official package registries, allowing any developer or user who installed them to be infected.

The incident affects developers, dYdX users, and any downstream applications that depend on the tainted libraries, potentially exposing cryptocurrency wallets and private keys. Because the attack targets the software supply chain, it demonstrates how trusted package ecosystems can be weaponized to compromise high‑value financial assets.

breaking_news.title: VMware ESXi sandbox‑escape vulnerability exploited in ransomware attacks
breaking_news.summary:
CISA confirmed that ransomware operators are actively exploiting CVE‑2025‑22225, a zero‑day arbitrary write vulnerability in VMware ESXi that enables a VM‑escape and full host compromise. The flaw, originally patched in March 2025, is being leveraged to gain privileged access to hypervisor environments and deploy ransomware payloads.

Enterprises, cloud service providers, and data‑center operators that run VMware ESXi are at immediate risk of ransomware infection and loss of control over virtualized workloads. The active exploitation of a hypervisor‑level zero‑day places this vulnerability in the critical category, demanding urgent patching and mitigation.

breaking_news.title: Active exploitation of critical SolarWinds Web Help Desk RCE flaw
breaking_news.summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) warned that CVE‑2025‑40551, an unauthenticated remote‑code‑execution vulnerability in SolarWinds Web Help Desk, is being actively exploited in the wild. Attackers can send crafted data to achieve code execution on vulnerable WHD instances, potentially compromising the underlying network.

SolarWinds WHD customers, including numerous U.S. federal agencies and private‑sector organizations, face immediate risk of system takeover and lateral movement. The rapid weaponization of this high‑severity flaw underscores the urgency for affected entities to apply the vendor’s patch and verify that no malicious activity has occurred.

breaking_news.title: React2Shell exploits NGINX servers to hijack web traffic
breaking_news.summary:
Researchers observed a coordinated campaign abusing the CVE‑2025‑55182 "React2Shell" vulnerability to compromise NGINX installations and popular Baota (BT) control panels, redirecting user traffic through attacker‑controlled infrastructure. The exploit chain leverages insecure NGINX configurations to inject malicious payloads and perform large‑scale traffic hijacking.

Websites and hosting providers that run vulnerable NGINX or Baota panels are exposed to data interception, credential theft, and further malware distribution. The widespread nature of the campaign and its focus on critical web‑infrastructure components elevate the threat to a high severity level.

breaking_news.title: Asian state‑backed group TGR‑STA‑1030 breaches 70 government and infrastructure targets
breaking_news.summary:
Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 disclosed that the previously unknown APT group TGR‑STA‑1030, operating from Asia, has infiltrated the networks of at least 70 government agencies and critical‑infrastructure organizations across 37 countries over the past year. The group conducts extensive reconnaissance, credential harvesting, and long‑term espionage against high‑value targets.

The compromised entities span energy, transportation, health, and public‑sector domains, exposing sensitive state data and potentially enabling disruptive operations. The breadth of the campaign and its state‑backed nature make it a high‑severity incident for any organization within the affected sectors.

breaking_news.title: Cyberspy Group hacks governments and critical infrastructure in 37 countries
breaking_news.summary:
Security researchers identified the Cyberspy Group, a China‑linked threat actor, as having compromised networks of governments and critical‑infrastructure operators in 37 nations. The group employs custom malware and credential‑stealing tools to maintain persistent access and exfiltrate strategic data.

Victims include ministries, utilities, and transportation systems, raising concerns about potential sabotage or intelligence theft. The scale and targeting of essential services place this activity in the high‑severity category for affected public‑sector and private‑sector entities.
